The **State of Origin** series is the annual best-of-three [rugby league
football](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") match series between two
Australian state representative sides, the [New South Wales
Blues](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New South Wales rugby league
team") and the [Queensland Maroons](/wiki/Queensland_rugby_league_team
"Queensland rugby league team").[1]

Referred to as Australian sport's greatest rivalry,[2][3][4][5][6] the State
of Origin series is one of Australia's premier sporting events, attracting
huge television audiences and usually selling out the stadiums in which the
games are played.[7] It is regularly described as being the pinnacle of rugby
league, even in comparison with international competitions.[8][9][10][11]

Players are selected to represent the [Australian
state](/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia "States and territories of
Australia") in which they played their first senior rugby league game, hence
the name 'state of origin'. Prior to 1980 players were only selected for
interstate matches on the basis of where they were playing their club football
at the time. In both 1980 and 1981 there were two interstate matches under the
old selection rules and one experimental "State of Origin" match. From 1982
onwards a best-of-three match series has been played around the middle of the
rugby league season for the State of Origin shield. During the early years,
the results were [extraordinarily
even](/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#Year_by_year "State of Origin series").
However, since 2006, Queensland has won every series except in 2014 and 2018.

##
Teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Teams")]

Since the 1908 establishment of [rugby league in
Australia](/wiki/Rugby_league_in_Australia "Rugby league in Australia"), the
sport's two major states, [New South
Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New South Wales rugby league
team") and [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_rugby_league_team "Queensland rugby
league team"), have played representative matches against each other which
have continued into the "state of origin" era which began in the 1980s. The
two states' teams are frequently referred to as the Blues and Maroons,
reflecting the respective colours of their jerseys. These were the colours of
the [Australia national rugby league
team](/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_league_team "Australia national rugby
league team")'s jersey until the adoption of the green and gold. The Blues
team is administered by the [New South Wales Rugby
League](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Rugby_League "New South Wales Rugby League") and
the Maroons by the [Queensland Rugby League](/wiki/Queensland_Rugby_League
"Queensland Rugby League"). The New South Wales team are sometimes referred to
by the nickname "[Cockroaches](/wiki/Cockroach "Cockroach")" and the
Queensland team as "[Cane Toads](/wiki/Cane_Toad "Cane Toad")", due to names
given to them by Barry Muir and Johnny Raper respectively. It was reinforced
by a marketing campaign used in the 1980s where the respective teams were
caricatured as such.

Whilst other Australian states also have representative rugby league teams,
they have not competed in State of Origin.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

### Interstate Rugby League prior to
1980[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Interstate Rugby League prior to 1980")]

The first calls for a state of origin selection policy in interstate [rugby
football](/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby football") came before the schism
between the union and league codes eventuated in Australia. In 1900 a
journalist known as 'The Cynic' wrote in _The Referee_ that star rugby player
and recent immigrant to Queensland, Stephen Spragg, should be able to play for
his home state of [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South
Wales").[[1]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
originoforigin)

Since the beginning of Australian rugby league in 1908, an interstate
competition between [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales")
and [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland "Queensland") has been conducted from time
to time. Until 1982 each team drew its players from the clubs based in that
state. No consideration was given to the origins of the players
themselves.[[2]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
rugreb)

The [first of these interstate
games](/wiki/1908_Interstate_rugby_league_series "1908 Interstate rugby league
series") was played at Sydney's Agricultural Ground on 11 July 1908, before
Queensland had even commenced its club competition. New South Wales easily
accounted for Queensland in a 43–0 victory. The local media were unimpressed.

    _There can be no doubt the NSW men are improving a good deal... They cannot be blamed for the farce, for it was nothing else. If the Australian team depends on Queenslanders to strengthen it, one is afraid it will be found wanting. They are quite the weakest lot of footballers I have even seen come down from Queensland. The play needs no detailed description as it was simply a practice match for NSW, and certainly did not advantageously advertise the new game._
    -[The Sydney Morning Herald](/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald "The Sydney Morning Herald"), 13 July 1908[[3]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-rugref)

The interstate series was dominated by New South Wales, apart from a golden
period for Queensland in the 1920s. From 1922 to 1925 Queensland defeated New
South Wales 11 times in 12 matches. At the end of the 1925 season a
[Kangaroo](/wiki/Australian_national_rugby_league_team "Australian national
rugby league team") team was to be picked for touring Great Britain. Instead
of announcing an Australian team dominated by Queenslanders, the [Australian
Rugby League Board of Control](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby
League") informed the media that the [Rugby Football
League](/wiki/Rugby_Football_League "Rugby Football League") had decided that
the [Kiwis](/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_league_team "New Zealand national
rugby league team") would provide stronger opposition, and that there would be
no Australian
tour.[[4]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
gallaway) The period spanning 1922 to 1929 saw no Australian team play in
Great Britain, the only such hiatus outside the two World
Wars.[[5]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-broncos)

The New South Wales dominance of interstate football increased after 1956 when
gaming machines were legalised for all registered clubs in New South Wales.
This provided New South Wales football clubs with a revenue source unmatched
by Queensland clubs. From this time on an increasing number of Queensland
players moved to the much stronger [Sydney
competition](/wiki/NSWRFL_premiership "NSWRFL premiership"), becoming
ineligible for Queensland state selection. [Paul Hogan](/wiki/Paul_Hogan "Paul
Hogan") famously told a Queensland Rugby League gathering in 1977 that "every
time Queensland produces a good footballer, he finishes up being processed
through a New South Wales poker
machine."[[6]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
gallaway)

Prior to 1956, NSW had won 75% and Qld only 25% of series played. From
1956–1981, NSW dominance soared even higher and Qld wins dwindled to only 3.8%
with only 1 series win, in 1959.

### Conception of State of Origin
football[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Conception of State of Origin football")]

By the 1970s the prestige of interstate matches had been seriously downgraded.
Matches were played mid-week, so as not to interfere with the Sydney club
competition, and the small crowds in New South Wales were hosted at suburban
grounds.[12] Interstate football reached its nadir in 1977 when the [New South
Wales Rugby Football League](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Rugby_Football_League "New
South Wales Rugby Football League") (NSWRFL) declined to host the Queensland
team, and both interstate games were played in
Queensland.[[7]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
gallaway)

Former Queensland captain and Australian vice-captain [Jack
Reardon](/wiki/Jack_Reardon "Jack Reardon"), who had later become a
journalist, was the first to suggest that Sydney-based Queenslanders should be
available for selection to represent their state.[13]

[Brisbane _Courier-Mail_](/wiki/The_Courier_Mail "The Courier Mail") reporter
[Hugh Lunn](/wiki/Hugh_Lunn "Hugh Lunn"), [Barry Maranta](/wiki/Barry_Maranta
"Barry Maranta") (the future co-founder of the [Brisbane
Broncos](/wiki/Brisbane_Broncos "Brisbane Broncos"))
[[8]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
originwebsite) and Maranta's business partner [Wayne Reid](/wiki/Wayne_Reid
"Wayne Reid") played a part in persuading QRL chairman [Ron
McAullife](/wiki/Ron_McAullife "Ron McAullife") that the concept could be used
in rugby
league.[[9]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
crikey) Lunn told McAullife that "you can take the Queenslander out of
Queensland, Ron, but you can't take the Queensland out of the
Queenslander."[[10]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
gallaway) McAuliffe was initially sceptical. "What if we recall our boys from
Sydney to play, and we are beaten. Where would we go from there?" Reid spoke
to NSWRFL president [Kevin Humphreys](/wiki/Kevin_Humphreys_\(rugby_league\)
"Kevin Humphreys \(rugby league\)") and suggested that a one-off state of
origin match could be used as a Test Match selection trial.
[[11]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-gallaway)

New South Wales clubs were reticent in their support of the concept and set
two conditions:

  * If the third game was to decide the series it was not to act as a selection trial, and also,
  * that the expatriate Queenslanders would be under the supervision of a representative of the NSWRFL whose duty it would be to protect the interests of both the NSWRFL and the clubs to which they were contracted. (From 1980 this role was filled by Bob Abbott, a [Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks](/wiki/Cronulla-Sutherland_Sharks "Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks") official.)

Three Sydney clubs remained opposed to the plan: [St. George
Dragons](/wiki/St._George_Dragons "St. George Dragons"), [South Sydney
Rabbitohs](/wiki/South_Sydney_Rabbitohs "South Sydney Rabbitohs") and [Eastern
Suburbs Roosters](/wiki/Sydney_Roosters "Sydney Roosters"). As these clubs
were refusing to release players, Humphreys threatened to make the game an
official [Australian Rugby League](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian
Rugby League") trial, which would make release mandatory. The clubs backed
down.[[12]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
mcgregor)

###
Experimentation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Experimentation")]

See also: [1980 State of Origin game](/wiki/1980_State_of_Origin_game "1980
State of Origin game") and [1981 State of Origin
game](/wiki/1981_State_of_Origin_game "1981 State of Origin game")

After Queensland lost the first two interstate matches in 1980 (35–3 and 17–7,
the second game in front of only 1,638 Sydneysiders) it was announced that [a
'state of origin' match](/wiki/1980_State_of_Origin_match "1980 State of
Origin match") would take place on 8 July at [Lang Park](/wiki/Lang_Park "Lang
Park") in Brisbane. The [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South
Wales") media gave both the event, and Queensland's chance of winning it,
little credence, calling the game a "three day wonder". Australia's 1978
captain [Bob Fulton](/wiki/Bob_Fulton "Bob Fulton") called the match "the non-
event of the century". Ron MacAullife however, was now committed to the
concept and vigorously promoted the match. Thousands of tickets were sold
before the game had been officially sanctioned. Although interstate matches in
Brisbane had still been well attended (24,653 had attended the opening match
of the 1979 series), few expected the sell-out crowd of 33,210 Queensland
rugby league fans, delighted to see their heroes in the likes of Arthur
Beetson representing their home state for the first time ever. Queensland
convincingly beat New South Wales
20–10.[[13]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
firstorigin)

> I was strongly against such a match, but last night's gripping clash showed
> that such a fixture would be a welcome addition to the League program.[14]
>
> — Alan Clarkson, journalist for _[The Sydney Morning
> Herald](/wiki/The_Sydney_Morning_Herald "The Sydney Morning Herald")_ , 6
> October 1980

In 1981 the first two interstate matches were again played under the old
selection rules. As New South Wales won the first two matches in the series,
state of origin selection rules were used once more in the third match.
Although New South Wales ran out to an early 15–0 lead in the game, Queensland
rallied to win 22–15.

###
Adoption[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Adoption")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e8/First_State_of_Origin_Shield.jpg/150px-
First_State_of_Origin_Shield.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_State_of_Origin_Shield.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:First_State_of_Origin_Shield.jpg "Enlarge")

The first State of Origin shield, depicting Queensland's [Wally
Lewis](/wiki/Wally_Lewis "Wally Lewis") and New South Wales' [Brett
Kenny](/wiki/Brett_Kenny "Brett Kenny").

The interest generated by the experimental state of origin matches of 1980 and
1981 and the potential for financial rewards were enough to convince the
authorities to play all three games under state of origin rules the following
year.[[14]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
originhistory)

> The State of Origin format is the only possible way to allow the interstate
> series to survive.
>
> — [Frank Hyde](/wiki/Frank_Hyde "Frank Hyde") (2 June 1982)[15]

Despite the Maroons' success so far in the State of Origin experiments, the
New South Wales media dismissed the seriousness of the Queensland threat to
the Blues' long-held dominance in series wins. Queensland however, under the
leadership of [immortal](/wiki/The_Immortals_\(rugby_league\) "The Immortals
\(rugby league\)") captain [Wally Lewis](/wiki/Wally_Lewis "Wally Lewis"), was
inspired by this, and for the first three State of Origin series Queensland
won 2 matches to 1.

However, in 1985, under the leadership of captain [Steve
Mortimer](/wiki/Steve_Mortimer "Steve Mortimer"), New South Wales won the
deciding match in front of 29,068 spectators at the [Sydney Cricket
Ground](/wiki/Sydney_Cricket_Ground "Sydney Cricket Ground"), claiming the
series for the first time. The following year the Blues were able to go one
better and complete the first state of origin whitewash, taking the series
3–0.[[15]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
originhistory)

### 1987: American
controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 1987: American controversy")]

After Queensland had won the 1987 series 2–1, a fourth game was played at
[Long Beach](/wiki/Long_Beach,_California "Long Beach, California"),
California to showcase [rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") to
the American
public.[[16]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_la-game)

In _Origin: Rugby League 's Greatest Contest 1980–2002_ (2003) Queensland
writer Jack Gallaway tells a story:

    There was one additional Origin contest played in 1987. The Queenslanders had climbed the mountain and at no point did they take the project seriously in any competitive sense. The State of Origin trophy was safely stowed in the [Queensland Rugby League](/wiki/Queensland_Rugby_League "Queensland Rugby League") board room at [Lang Park](/wiki/Suncorp_Stadium "Suncorp Stadium"), and for the Maroons the visit to the United States was their end-of-season outing, the game an exhibition... Such was the Blues' disappointment at the loss of the State of Origin series that they would go to any length to restore some vestige of their lost pride. The [New South Wales Rugby League](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Rugby_League "New South Wales Rugby League") hierarchy told their men to prepare for the contest as though it was a deciding test match.[[17]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-gallaway) The match was played at the [Veterans Memorial Stadium](/wiki/Veterans_Memorial_Stadium_\(Long_Beach\) "Veterans Memorial Stadium \(Long Beach\)") in Long Beach, California in front of 12,349 fans. The Blues won the game 30–18.

In 1987 the [Australian Rugby League](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League
"Australian Rugby League") (ARL), [New South Wales Rugby
League](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Rugby_League "New South Wales Rugby League") and
[Queensland Rugby League](/wiki/Queensland_Rugby_League "Queensland Rugby
League") agreed that the match would only count towards the players'
individual statistics. On 15 July 2003 the [Australian Rugby
League](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby League") (whose
primary members are originally from the New South Wales Rugby League)
announced that the fourth 1987 game was to be classified as an official match,
and that a win in the state of origin match on 16 July 2003 would take New
South Wales into the overall lead.

ARL and NSWRL chief executive [Geoff Carr](/wiki/Geoff_Carr "Geoff Carr")
said: "There had been some debate over whether the Origin fixture . . . in
1987 was counted as an official match but a search of ARL records has
confirmed the status conferred on that clash by the game's governing body at
the time. In announcing the match in Big League in April 1987, [Ken
Arthurson](/wiki/Ken_Arthurson "Ken Arthurson"), the ARL's chief executive in
1987, was quoted as saying 'It's an exciting experiment but the match isn't
and won't be billed as an exhibition match'."

###
1990s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 1990s")]

After the controversy of the match played in the United States, the Queensland
halves pairing of [Allan Langer](/wiki/Allan_Langer "Allan Langer") and [Wally
Lewis](/wiki/Wally_Lewis "Wally Lewis") led the Maroons in their 3–0 series
wins in both 1988 and 1989. The rise of the Canberra Raiders in the then
Winfield Cup club competition produced for the Blues the formidable halves
combination of [Ricky Stuart](/wiki/Ricky_Stuart "Ricky Stuart") and [Laurie
Daley](/wiki/Laurie_Daley "Laurie Daley") who brought New South Wales back
from defeat with two wins in the opening games of the 1990 series. It was
evident that as the rivalry between the two states grew, the Origin matches
had become much more physical forward orientated game than the open running
play seen in earlier
series.[[18]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-
originhistory)

As the great Queensland players from the 1980s began to retire from the game,
the Maroons struggled with a team of fresh faces and considerable
inexperience. The 1992, 1993 and 1994 series all went to NSW as the talent and
experience of Blues players such as [Brett Mullins](/wiki/Brett_Mullins "Brett
Mullins"), Daley and Stuart in the backs and [Benny Elias](/wiki/Benny_Elias
"Benny Elias") and [Bradley Clyde](/wiki/Bradley_Clyde "Bradley Clyde") in the
forwards gave the Blues the edge when the games were on the line. It wasn't
until the upheaval of the [Super League war](/wiki/Super_League_war "Super
League war") in 1995 that the Maroons were able to again clinch a series.

A main cause for concern for Queensland was the fact that the [Brisbane
Broncos](/wiki/Brisbane_Broncos "Brisbane Broncos"), its players and many
other Queenslanders were not aligned with the
[ARL](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby League") prohibiting any
players signed with the [Super League](/wiki/Super_League "Super League") to
play for the Maroons. Despite this the Queenslanders won the 1995 series 3–0
in a shocking white-wash. The 1996 series saw the off-field contract dramas
put aside as all players were allowed, regardless of contract, state of origin
selection. Having the majority of the Queenslanders back didn't help the
Maroons though as the Blues 1996 white-wash with a 3–0 series win of their
own.

The Australian game divided in 1997 into two competitions, one run by the
[ARL](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby League") and one by the
News Limited-owned [Super League](/wiki/Super_League "Super League"), and an
interstate series was played in each. Under the Super League banner there was
a Tri-Origin series with a New Zealand side added to the competition. The
[ARL](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby League") meanwhile stuck
to its traditional format. The teams were selected using origin rules, and New
South Wales and Queensland met twice. These matches do not count towards the
official state of origin record. As with the premiership, players were spread
between two representative tournaments as well.

The competitions merged again in 1998 as the current [National Rugby
League](/wiki/National_Rugby_League "National Rugby League"), and the series
that year proved to be enthralling as both sides won a game each away from
home, setting up a decider at the Sydney Football Stadium where 39,000 fans
witnessed the visiting Queenslanders take the series 2–1. The end of the
decade saw a dramatic series with each side taking one game each and game
three ending in a draw. Queensland were awarded the series as at the time the
previous winners retained the interstate honours.

###
2000s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: 2000s")]

The early to mid-2000s saw New South Wales starting to assert its traditional
interstate dominance, causing some critics [who?] to question the future of
State of Origin. However, this imbalance tipped in the third and deciding game
of the [2006 State of Origin series](/wiki/2006_State_of_Origin_series "2006
State of Origin series"), which is seen as the starting point of Queensland's
unprecedented dynasty. Queensland followed by winning the [2007
series](/wiki/2007_State_of_Origin_series "2007 State of Origin series"), as
well as the [2008 series](/wiki/2008_State_of_Origin_series "2008 State of
Origin series"), which made Queensland's streak three series in a row. [New
South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Rugby_League_team "New South Wales Rugby
League team") won Game 1 on 21 May 2008, however Queensland won Game 2 on 11
June 2008, and Game 3 on 2 July 2008. Queensland continued to follow this up
by winning the first two games of the 2009 series becoming the first state to
win four series in a row.

###
2010s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: 2010s")]

In 2010, Queensland won its historic, record-breaking, fifth consecutive
Origin series with a 23–18 win in the third and final match. This was the
first Queensland team to win all three consecutive State of Origin Games in 15
years. Queensland full back Billy Slater won man of the match in the third
game and was awarded the Wally Lewis Medal as Man of the Series in 2010. The
2010 State of Origin series was also the second televised program in Australia
to be shot in [3D](/wiki/3-D_film "3-D film") [1080i](/wiki/1080i "1080i")
[DVB-T](/wiki/DVB-T "DVB-T") as well as being simultaneously broadcast in
regular [576i](/wiki/576i "576i") and [1080i](/wiki/1080i "1080i")
[DVB-T](/wiki/DVB-T "DVB-T") and [PAL](/wiki/PAL "PAL").

In the first game of the 2011 series Queensland defeated New South Wales
16–12. In the second game New South Wales defeated Queensland 18–8. Queensland
won the series 34–24 in the 2011 decider in what was Queensland captain Darren
Lockyer's 36th and final game. Cameron Smith won man of the match in both the
first and third game and was awarded the Wally Lewis Medal as Man of the
Series.

In 2012, then NRL CEO [David Gallop](/wiki/David_Gallop "David Gallop")
introduced the Under-20s State of Origin for [Toyota
Cup](/wiki/2012_National_Youth_Competition_season_\(rugby_league\) "2012
National Youth Competition season \(rugby league\)") players which saw New
South Wales winning. Queensland went on to win a historic 7th series win in
2012, winning the final game by 1 point.

In 2013, New South Wales defeated Queensland 14 to 6 in game 1, Queensland
defeated New South Wales 26 to 6 in game 2, while in game 3 Queensland
defeated New South Wales 12 to 10 to take out the overall Origin title for the
eighth consecutive time. The 2013 series set a new State of Origin television
ratings record for a whole series since the 2001 introduction of the ratings
system.[16]

In 2014, New South Wales defeated Queensland 12-8 in the first game of the
series, and 6-4 in the second.[17] In the third game Queensland defeated New
South Wales 32-8 after scoring the first try of the game in the 37th minute,
with Queensland leading 6-2 in the first half. This gave the Blues the first
series win in 8 years.

In 2015, Queensland defeated New South Wales 11-10 in game 1 played in Sydney,
New South Wales defeated Queensland 26-18 in game 2 played in Melbourne,
Queensland defeated New South Wales 52-6 in game 3 played in Brisbane, winning
the series 2-1.

In 2016, Queensland defeated New South Wales 6-4 in game 1 and clinched the
series with a 26-16 win in the second match. New South Wales closed off the
series with a 18-14 win over Queensland.

In 2017, New South Wales won Game 1, 28-4 sparking the New South Wales media
to start proclaiming the beginning of the Blues Dynasty.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Queensland won Game 2, 18-16 after making changes to the team with the
returning Billy Slater and Johnathan Thurston, who kicked the winning goal for
Queensland. Thurston injured his shoulder in the 30th minute of the match,
essentially disabling it as he played out the whole match. Thurston was later
ruled out for the rest of the year after scans revealed his shoulder needed a
reconstruction, ending his representative career as he announced 2017 would be
his last representative year. In Game 3, New South Wales went in with an
unchanged lineup for all three games, the first to do so since 1996.
Queensland dominated the Blues, winning 22-6, with Queensland winger Dane
Gagai winning the Wally Lewis Medal for Best Player in the series. It also had
Johnathan Thurston raise the Origin Shield with Queensland Captain Cameron
Smith, before being chaired off the ground by his teammates, ending Thurston's
representative career on a high note.

In 2018, New South Wales won their first State of Origin series in four years,
defeating Queensland 22–12 and 18–14 in the first two games. Queensland scored
a consolation victory 18–12 in the final game.

##
Popularity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Popularity")]

In 2013, each individual game in the series drew a higher Australian
television audience than any other sporting event.[18] In recent years the
series has gained popularity outside of New South Wales and Queensland, with
games played in [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") drawing record crowds
for rugby league[19] and local television ratings comparable to those of some
[Victorian](/wiki/Victoria_\(Australia\) "Victoria \(Australia\)")
[AFL](/wiki/Australian_Football_League "Australian Football League")
matches.[20] Internationally, the series is televised in 91 countries,[21] and
is a national obsession in [Papua New Guinea](/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea "Papua
New Guinea"), occasionally sparking riots, violence and deaths.[22][23] It
also draws a strong following in neighbouring [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand
"New Zealand").[24]

##
Broadcasting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Broadcasting")]

Within Australia, [Nine Network](/wiki/Nine_Network "Nine Network") is the
main broadcaster for the series, with replays airing on [Fox
Sports](/wiki/Fox_Sports_\(Australia\) "Fox Sports \(Australia\)"). The series
is also broadcast on radio by [ABC Grandstand](/wiki/ABC_Grandstand "ABC
Grandstand").

[Setanta Sports](/wiki/Setanta_Sports_Asia "Setanta Sports Asia") broadcasts
live matches in Asia. In the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States"), [Fox Soccer](/wiki/Fox_Soccer "Fox Soccer") televised all matches
live using the Nine feed since 2011, with the coverage moving to [Fox Sports
2](/wiki/Fox_Sports_2 "Fox Sports 2") when Fox Soccer was discontinued in
August 2013.[25][26] [Premier Sports](/wiki/Premier_Sports "Premier Sports")
broadcasts live coverage of State of Origin in the UK.

Another twist on the coverage was [Roy and HG's State of Origin
commentary](/wiki/Roy_and_HG%27s_State_of_Origin_commentary "Roy and HG's
State of Origin commentary") on Australian youth radio network [Triple
J](/wiki/Triple_J "Triple J"). This broadcast was presented by the characters
"Rampaging" [Roy Slaven](/wiki/Roy_Slaven "Roy Slaven") and [HG
Nelson](/wiki/Greig_Pickhaver "Greig Pickhaver") (played by [John
Doyle](/wiki/John_Doyle_\(comedian\) "John Doyle \(comedian\)") and [Greig
Pickhaver](/wiki/Greig_Pickhaver "Greig Pickhaver")), who commentated the game
with a unique comedic style. Roy and HG's broadcasts began in the late 1980s,
and continued until 2008. Roy and HG moved from Triple J to radio network
[Triple M](/wiki/Triple_M "Triple M") in 2009, at which point the duo ceased
their State of Origin commentary.

###
Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Controversy")]

From time to time the selection of players under the [State of
Origin](/wiki/State_of_Origin "State of Origin") rules creates controversy.
Since 1980, Queensland has completed just the 7 series with a team completely
made up of players of a Queensland birth, while for New South Wales the total
is only 6.[27] However, place of birth has only been a relevant factor in
eligibility since 2012.

An issue of contention has been the selection of players such as [Peter
Sterling](/wiki/Peter_Sterling "Peter Sterling"), [Ken Nagas](/wiki/Ken_Nagas
"Ken Nagas"), [James McManus](/wiki/James_McManus_\(rugby_league\) "James
McManus \(rugby league\)"), [Israel Folau](/wiki/Israel_Folau "Israel Folau")
and [Greg Inglis](/wiki/Greg_Inglis "Greg Inglis"). Israel Folau was born and
raised in New South Wales but is eligible to play for Queensland as he played
his first senior rugby league match in Queensland. [Ken Nagas](/wiki/Ken_Nagas
"Ken Nagas") was born and raised in Queensland but decided to play for New
South Wales, [Peter Sterling](/wiki/Peter_Sterling "Peter Sterling") was born
in Toowoomba, Queensland and raised in Wagga Wagga, Newcastle & Sydney, all in
New South Wales, while McManus was born in Scotland and was raised in the
Northern Territory, but was ruled eligible to play for New South Wales in the
2009 series.

The selection of [Greg Inglis](/wiki/Greg_Inglis "Greg Inglis") by
[Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_rugby_league_team "Queensland rugby league
team") was disputed. The [Queensland Rugby
League](/wiki/Queensland_Rugby_League "Queensland Rugby League") selected him
based on the fact that either [Wavell State High
School](/wiki/Wavell_State_High_School "Wavell State High School") or
[Brisbane Norths](/wiki/Brisbane_Norths "Brisbane Norths") was Inglis' first
senior football, making him eligible for both states per the rules at the
time.[28][29][30] However Inglis had previously played for Hunter Sports High
School in [Newcastle, New South Wales](/wiki/Newcastle,_New_South_Wales
"Newcastle, New South Wales"), in the [Arrive Alive
Cup](/wiki/Arrive_Alive_Cup "Arrive Alive Cup"); considered to be a senior
competition. Hunter Sports High coach Steve Dunn said "there was some talk the
other day that he was actually brought to Queensland before his 16th birthday
but I was coach of the team. He played for us at 16, he's a Blue".[31] The
controversy led to the creation of the "[That's In
Queensland](/wiki/That%27s_In_Queensland "That's In Queensland")" viral video.

Due to the clarification of selection rules the Sims brothers are eligible for
different States. [Tariq](/wiki/Tariq_Sims "Tariq Sims") and
[Ashton](/wiki/Ashton_Sims "Ashton Sims") are eligible for New South Wales
while [Korbin Sims](/wiki/Korbin_Sims "Korbin Sims") is eligible for
Queensland.[32] Previously father and son combinations, such as
[Steve](/wiki/Steve_Rogers_\(rugby_league\) "Steve Rogers \(rugby league\)")
and [Mat Rogers](/wiki/Mat_Rogers "Mat Rogers") have represented different
states. This duo was especially notable because Mat was born in New South
Wales and played for Queensland while Steve was born in Queensland and played
for New South Wales. Steve Rogers played his first senior game of rugby league
for the Southport Tigers on Queenslands Gold Coast

Foreign born players have also represented each state. New Zealand has had
several players, such as [Brad Thorn](/wiki/Brad_Thorn "Brad Thorn"), [Ben
Te'o](/wiki/Ben_Te%27o "Ben Te'o"), [Craig
Smith](/wiki/Craig_Smith_\(rugby_league_born_1971\) "Craig Smith \(rugby
league born 1971\)"), [Willie Mason](/wiki/Willie_Mason "Willie Mason"),
[Tonie Carroll](/wiki/Tonie_Carroll "Tonie Carroll"), [James
Tamou](/wiki/James_Tamou "James Tamou") and [Karmichael
Hunt](/wiki/Karmichael_Hunt "Karmichael Hunt") play Origin. Tamou's selection
by New South Wales in 2012 was controversial as he was born in [Palmerston
North](/wiki/Palmerston_North "Palmerston North") and played for the Junior
Kiwis, lived in New Zealand until he moved to Sydney when he was 13 and was
included in the [New Zealand Kiwis](/wiki/New_Zealand_Kiwis "New Zealand
Kiwis") training squad for the [2011 Four
Nations](/wiki/2011_Rugby_League_Four_Nations "2011 Rugby League Four
Nations").[33] Both Hunt and Tamou played for
[Australia](/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_league_team "Australia national
rugby league team") before being selected for State of Origin. Other players,
such as [Sam Kasiano](/wiki/Sam_Kasiano "Sam Kasiano") and [Jason
Taumalolo](/wiki/Jason_Taumalolo "Jason Taumalolo") are also eligible,
creating concern in the [New Zealand Rugby
League](/wiki/New_Zealand_Rugby_League "New Zealand Rugby League").[34] Apart
from representing Queensland, Brad Thorn is also a dual rugby international,
having played international rugby league for Australia, and international
rugby union for the [All Blacks](/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team
"New Zealand national rugby union team").

Papua New Guinea-born [Adrian Lam](/wiki/Adrian_Lam "Adrian Lam") and Fijian-
born [Lote Tuqiri](/wiki/Lote_Tuqiri "Lote Tuqiri"), [Akuila
Uate](/wiki/Akuila_Uate "Akuila Uate") and [Petero
Civoniceva](/wiki/Petero_Civoniceva "Petero Civoniceva") have also played
Origin. [Benny Elias](/wiki/Benny_Elias "Benny Elias") was born in Lebanon and
has played for and captained NSW. [Mario Fenech](/wiki/Mario_Fenech "Mario
Fenech") was born in Malta and has played for NSW. The most recent case of a
foreign born player being selected was the selection of former Samoan
international, [Ben Te'o](/wiki/Ben_Te%27o "Ben Te'o"), by Queensland in game
three of the 2012 season.[35]

A report into eligibility based on a player's birth state showed; "Of the 18
series that QLD has won, it had the greater percentage of non-State [born]
players in its side on 14 of those occasions – revealing a 77.8% dependency.
Of the 13 series that NSW has won, on five of those occasions it had the
higher percentage of non-State [born] players across the series – revealing a
38.5% dependency."[27]

###
Anomalies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Anomalies")]

  1. In 1995 and 1997 [Super League](/wiki/Super_League_\(Australia\) "Super League \(Australia\)") players were made ineligible for the [ARL](/wiki/Australian_Rugby_League "Australian Rugby League") State of Origin series selection. This included most of Queensland's usual team, who now played for the Super League affiliated [Brisbane Broncos](/wiki/Brisbane_Broncos "Brisbane Broncos"). The ARL hence decided to relax the rules in those years, allowing Queensland to select [Adrian Lam](/wiki/Adrian_Lam "Adrian Lam") who had previously played for [Papua New Guinea](/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea_national_rugby_league_team "Papua New Guinea national rugby league team"). The 1995 Origin series was the scene of the biggest upset in Origin history when the relatively inexperienced Maroon's swept aside NSW, who even without their Super League players could still boast a number of senior Origin and international players, 3-0.
  2. During the [2000 World Cup](/wiki/2000_Rugby_League_World_Cup "2000 Rugby League World Cup") a number of Australian players were granted dispensations to appear for other nations under the [grandparent rule](/wiki/Grandparent_rule "Grandparent rule"). The players affected were [David Barnhill](/wiki/David_Barnhill "David Barnhill") (NSW), [Kevin Campion](/wiki/Kevin_Campion_\(rugby_league\) "Kevin Campion \(rugby league\)") (Qld), [Tonie Carroll](/wiki/Tonie_Carroll "Tonie Carroll") (Qld), [Graham Mackay](/wiki/Graham_Mackay "Graham Mackay") (NSW), [Willie Mason](/wiki/Willie_Mason "Willie Mason") (NSW), [Luke Ricketson](/wiki/Luke_Ricketson "Luke Ricketson") (NSW), [Lote Tuqiri](/wiki/Lote_Tuqiri "Lote Tuqiri") (Qld) and [Adrian Vowles](/wiki/Adrian_Vowles "Adrian Vowles") (Qld), [[21]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-nswplayers) [[22]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_Origin_series#endnote_ref-rlwc2000)

### Year by
year[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Year by year")]

Of the 36 full series played, Queensland have won 21, New South Wales 14, with
2 series drawn (Queensland retained the Shield on both occasions as the
previous year's winner). With the addition of three one-off games that were
played in 1980, 1981 and 1987, the total number of games played is 108.
Queensland have won 58, New South Wales have won 51, with 2 matches being
drawn.[36]

The series of 1999 and 2002 are considered drawn series, as both New South
Wales and Queensland won a single game of each 3 match series, with the final
game concluding in a draw. At that time there was no overtime rule to break
the deadlock, and by the same set of rules, Queensland retained the shield as
they were the previous holders, but did not win the series. Due to controversy
around the second drawn series, and the rule awarding the series champions to
Queensland, the rules were subsequently changed to rule out drawn matches and
series. Equal points at the close of full-time are now resolved with the
[golden point](/wiki/Golden_point "Golden point") method.

## Under
20s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Under 20s")]

The Under 20s State of Origin has only had seven seasons so far (2012 to
2018)[37] with only one game a year, instead of three. New South Wales has won
six of the seven, with Queensland winning their first in 2018[38]. They play
for the Darren Lockyer Shield.

Year | Winner | Wins | Losses | Drawn

## Women's State of
Origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Women's State of Origin")]

The Women's State of Origin is the [Women's rugby
league](/wiki/Women%27s_rugby_league "Women's rugby league") version of the
game, and has been running since 1999. The players play for the Nellie Doherty
Cup. Furthermore, the current record for series won in the competition rests
with Queensland, who won every series from 1999-2014, a better straight record
than their male counterparts.
